Vital statistics
The National Institute of Statistics is the
government organ that facilitates and organizes
official statistics in the national statistical system.

disseminating data.
The production of vital statistics from civil
registration is very low or non-existent in
Cameroon. To date, the little data available are
those from MICS and DHS. In fact, the laws and
regulations relating to civil registration and those
governing the national statistical system do
not take into account the need for coordination
between the National Institute of Statistics and
BUNEC for the production of reliable vital statistics
from a civil registration.

indicators.justification:
The Constitution of 18 January 1996 of the Republic of Cameroon stipulates that the Supreme Court is the highest jurisdiction in "judicial, administrative and auditing matters". It provides for the existence of a chamber of accounts within this court. According to Article 41 of the Constitution, "the Chamber of Accounts is competent to control and rule on public accounts and those of public and semi-public companies. It shall give a sovereign decision on the final decisions of the lower courts of audit.

The legal framework is laid down by the law of 21 April 2003 on the powers, organisation and functioning of the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court, which is an independent isntitution exercising control on governance and transparency in the management of public affairs. 

Sources:

(1) Cameroon Constitution of 1996 : https://www.assnat.cm/images/The_constitution.pdf

(2) Law of 21 April 2003 on the powers, organisation and functioning of the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court (available in French online )  http://www.cvuc-uccc.com/minat/textes/15.pdf

(3) http://bibliotheque.pssfp.net/index.php/institutions/institutions-nationales/chambre-des-comptes/1586-annual-report-2013/file

indicators.justification:
There is no evidence to testify that political finance information in Cameroon is available as open data. 
However, there is an institution responsible for receiving and examining financial reports from political parties and/or candidates and for investigating violations. This Special Institution (Committee) set up by a Decree of the President of the Republic, under the supervision of Elections Cameroon, which is an independent body responsible for the organisation, management and supervision of all election operations and referendums. But there are no reporting requirements set out in the relevant laws.

Sources : 
(1) https://www.idea.int/data-tools/country-view/80/55 / Cameroon Profile 
(2) Section 277(1) of the Electoral Code: "A control commission is hereby instituted to verify, on the basis of supporting documents, that the use of funds by political parties or candidates conforms to the purpose of this law."

(3) Law N° 2006/011 of 29 December 2006 To set up and lay down the organisation and functioning of Elections Cameroon (ELECAM) - ONLINE VERSION (we could not get the downloadable version) https://www.spm.gov.cm/site/?q=fr/content/loi-n%C2%B0-2006011-du-29-d%C3%A9cembre-2006-portant-cr%C3%A9ation-organisation-et-fonctionnement-de

indicators.justification:
There is no formal framework requiring collection or publication of beneficial ownership data on companies. Requirements to publish this as open data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance, namely the EITI framework and associated standards requirements.

As of 1 January 2020, the EITI Standard requires that implementing countries request, and
companies disclose, beneficial ownership information (Requirement 2.5). This requirement
applies to companies that apply for or hold participating interests in a country's extractive sector and requires disclosure of their beneficial owners, the level of ownership and details about how
ownership or control is exerted. To achieve this Standard in most implementing countries, new
legislation may be necessary to provide the government with authority to collect beneficial
ownership information. In a few countries, however, it will be possible to build on existing laws
combatting corruption, money laundering and terrorist financing which already require beneficial
ownership disclosure.

indicators.justification:
Currently, there is no general data protection law or privacy law in Cameroon. The preparation of a general data protection bill is ongoing, spearheaded by the services of the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications. This "Privacy Bill" is expected to govern the collection, processing, transmitting, storage, and use of data. As a specific data protection law is still yet to be adopted, it is quite challenging for users to control the use of their data. Nevertheless, the issue of protecting data has become a regulatory and legislative concern in Cameroon. 
Data protection is a right enshrined in the Constitution of the Republic of Cameroon, Law No. 96/6 of 18 January 1996 revising the Constitution of 02 June 1972, as amended and supplemented by Law No. 2008/001 of 14 April 2008, which provides for the right to protection against any privacy interference and for the right to the privacy of correspondence. Legal and privacy-oriented provisions on data protection are also found in various pieces of legislation and governing texts, as well as in landmark case law.

(1)	Cameroon Constitution 1996  : https://www.assnat.cm/images/The_constitution.pdf

indicators.justification:
In Cameroon, the publication of information is based on one fundamental principle: the obligation to communicate information. Information held by public authorities is released on the basis of a simple request made by any citizen to the head of the institution whose permission is then required.
The mechanisms of dissemination or diffusion of information by the administration distinguish between
- formal channels (with a legal or regulatory basis) and 
- Informal channels (resulting from an effort by the administration to adapt to the local context). 
In Cameroon, the centralisation of computerised or digital data is the responsibility of the National Institute of Statistics (INS). However, the institution in charge of electoral processes in Cameroon, Elections Cameroon (ELECAM), has a service for collecting data and statistical files on this subject.

In addition to that, The promotion of the right to information is effective and organized by a few  legislative and regulatory texts that unfortunately lack binding force as concerns publication of data . These include :

(1) Law N°90/052 of December 19, 1990 on the freedom of social communication ( not available online)

(2) Decree N° 2000/158 of April 3, 2000 to lay down the conditions for the creation and operation of private audio-visual communication companies : https://barreaucameroun.org/site/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Decret-Audiovisuel-Conditions-N-2000-158-du-03-avril-2000.pdf

(3) LAW N° 2006/018 OF DECEMBER 29, 2006, GOVERNING ADVERTISING IN CAMEROON : https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Cameroon/Cameroon%20-%20Law%20No.%202006_018%20on%20Ads.pdf

Adding to that, there are provision on free or subsidized access to media for political parties, namely Section 15 of Law n°90/056 of 19 december 1990 relating to political parties.

Other Sources:
(1) Cameroon Constitution : http://www.assnat.cm/images/The_constitution.pdf

(2) https://rulemaking.worldbank.org/en/data/explorecountries/cameroon / Global Indicators of Regulatory Governance

indicators.justification:
In Cameroon, the field of public procurement is very complex. It is difficult to follow the procurement process. 
Calls for tenders are published in the state-owned newspaper, the Cameroon Tribune, and sometimes on the platforms of the Ministry of Public Procurement or certain ministries. the Cameroon Online E-procurement System COLEPS is the major online tool. 

But information or data on awards, procurement and even on the companies that win these contracts are sometimes difficult to obtain. 

Generally the public is satisfied with the communiqués that are made public about the nature, goods and services.

If some data is available, then it will be published in French or English. 
Data are never published in the languages of the country.

Sources : 
(1) The Cameroon On-Line e-Procurement System: http://marchespublics.cm/index.do 

(2) https://minmap.cm/wp-content/uploads/coleps/guide-Commissions.pdf
